title: 110_s1879
content: The educational assistance for members of the Selected Reserve is increased under the amendments made to Section 16131(b)(1) of title 10, United States Code. The amounts for educational assistance allowances are raised to $600, $450, and $300 respectively. These amendments will take effect upon the enactment of the Act and apply to payments made for months starting from that date. SEC. 2. REDUCTION IN RETIREMENT AGE FOR ARMED FORCES MEMBERS OF NATIONAL GUARD AND RESERVE WHO SERVE AFTER SEPTEMBER 11, 2001. Section 12731 of title 10, United States Code, is amended to set the eligibility age for retirement benefits at 60 years of age. For individuals who served on active duty in Iraq or Afghanistan after September 11, 2001, the eligibility age can be reduced by six months for every 90 days of service, with a limit of one reduction per 90-day period. The eligibility age for retirement benefits under section 12731 of title 10, United States Code, can be reduced by six months for every 90 days of service in Iraq or Afghanistan after September 11, 2001, with a limit of one reduction per 90-day period. The eligibility age may not be reduced below 50 years of age for any individual. Additionally, provisions of law or policy referring to retired pay eligibility before age 60 shall now reference the eligibility age under subsection (f) of section 12731. The amendment made by subsection (a) will be effective as of September 11, 2001, and will apply to applications for retired pay under section 12731(a) of title 10, United States Code, submitted after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Location of treatment for reserves with wounds or injuries from active duty. Location of Treatment for Reserves with Wounds or Injuries from Active Duty: Members requiring treatment for over 30 days for wounds or injuries incurred on active duty must be transferred to a suitable medical facility within 30 miles of a location chosen by the member, such as their hometown or permanent duty station. Transfers can be made to military medical facilities, Department of Veterans Affairs facilities, or private medical facilities. Transfers of members with wounds or injuries from active duty to medical facilities of the Department of Veterans Affairs or private facilities must be made on a space-available basis or with consent. Costs of treatment at these facilities will be covered for the specific wound or injury. The Secretary of the military department will bear the costs of treatment for wounds or injuries transferred to medical facilities. Amendments to enhance travel and transportation for family members of uniformed services members undergoing treatment include a daily allowance of $100 for up to 5 days in a 30-day period during a 180-day treatment period. During a 180-day treatment period, the Secretary of the military department will cover costs for wounds or injuries transferred to medical facilities. Amendments include a daily allowance of $100 for not more than 5 days in each consecutive 60-day period, followed by a 90-day period thereafter. Subsection (d), paragraph (3) is to be struck. SEC. 4. TRAVEL AND TRANSPORTATION ALLOWANCE FOR NATIONAL GUARD MEMBERS TRAVELING LONG DISTANCES FOR DRILL OR ANNUAL TRAINING. Sec. 408a of Chapter 7 of title 37, United States Code, allows reimbursement for National Guard members traveling over 50 miles for drill or annual training. The reimbursement is limited to the cost of government-procured commercial round-trip travel. (b) Clerical Amendment.--Inserting a new item after section 408 in chapter 7 of title 37, United States Code. Travel and transportation allowances for National Guard members traveling long distances for drill or annual training.
